Biology_423_r.News Finding: All these relations together form a robust network of interactions between plants and pollinators.
Biology_423_r.Paper Finding: The extent to which pollinators interact with the same plant species increases with connectance and/or nestedeness.
Biology_423_r.News Context: All these relations together form a robust network of interactions between plants and pollinators. These networks have a characteristic structure that is similar in very different natural landscapes, such as rainforests and river deltas, as well as in human-dominated landscapes with orchards, fields and meadows. Plants and pollinators take a position within those networks that makes the benefit from their mutual relationships for each species individually, and for all plants and pollinators together, as large as possible.
Biology_423_r.Paper Context: Our results can be understood intuitively by considering the 'net effects' of species on each other and the way in which these effects are mediated by the topology of mutualistic networks. The extent to which pollinators interact with the same plant species increases with connectance and/or nestedeness. A high nestedness of the mutualistic network may therefore promote the occurrence of indirect positive effects between pollinators.
Biology_423_r.text: ['Finding: All these relations together form a robust network of interactions between plants and pollinators.']
Biology_423_r.displayed_text: Finding: All these relations together form a robust network of interactions between plants and pollinators.

Biology_tweet_4_r.News Finding: Healthy Gut Bacteria Can Extend Lifespan:
Biology_tweet_4_r.Paper Finding: Our study demonstrates that regulating host/commensal interactions in barrier epithelia can significantly delay age-related pathologies and extend lifespan.
Biology_tweet_4_r.News Context: Healthy Gut Bacteria Can Extend Lifespan:
Biology_tweet_4_r.Paper Context: Further studies are needed to resolve this question. Our study demonstrates that regulating host/commensal interactions in barrier epithelia can significantly delay age-related pathologies and extend lifespan. We show here, however, that lifespan extension can be achieved by improving innate immune homeostasis to stabilize the gut microbiota rather than by eliminating all bacteria from the gut.
Biology_tweet_4_r.text: ['Finding: Healthy Gut Bacteria Can Extend Lifespan: ']
Biology_tweet_4_r.displayed_text: Finding: Healthy Gut Bacteria Can Extend Lifespan:

Biology_tweet_137_r.News Finding: Negative selection in cancer, after all...and it's also the immune system! Great work by @username @username and colleagues out in @username
Biology_tweet_137_r.Paper Finding: We present evidence for extensive negative selection over somatic point mutations in cancer exomes.
Biology_tweet_137_r.News Context: Negative selection in cancer, after all...and it's also the immune system! Great work by @username @username and colleagues out in @username
Biology_tweet_137_r.Paper Context: These studies help to shed light upon the mechanisms underlying immune evasion and provide insights for improving cancer immunotherapies in the future. We present evidence for extensive negative selection over somatic point mutations in cancer exomes. We exploited a large cancer exome dataset based on 26 tumor types and uncovered a set of 25 genes under negative selection (cancer-essential) and a set of 14 genes under positive selection (cancer drivers).
Biology_tweet_137_r.text: ['Finding: Negative selection in cancer, after all...and it\'s also the immune system! Great work by @username @username and colleagues out in @username ']
Biology_tweet_137_r.displayed_text: Finding: Negative selection in cancer, after all...and it's also the immune system! Great work by @username @username and colleagues out in @username

Biology_tweet_37_r.News Finding: Dr. G. Mills of WildCRU et al. show how cheetah hunting tactics vary according to their  prey via @username
Biology_tweet_37_r.Paper Finding: Rather, we suggest that cheetah chases comprise two primary phases: (i) an initial rapid acceleration resulting in high speed to quickly catch up with prey, followed by (ii) a prey-specific slowing period that enables the cheetah to match turns instigated by prey as the distance between them closes.
Biology_tweet_37_r.News Context: Dr. G. Mills of WildCRU et al. show how cheetah hunting tactics vary according to their  prey via @username
Biology_tweet_37_r.Paper Context: Thus, the widely held belief that cheetah hunts consist of simple highspeed chases seems an oversimplification. Rather, we suggest that cheetah chases comprise two primary phases: (i) an initial rapid acceleration resulting in high speed to quickly catch up with prey, followed by (ii) a prey-specific slowing period that enables the cheetah to match turns instigated by prey as the distance between them closes. However, this formulation only considered forward acceleration and speed, ignoring lateral acceleration.
Biology_tweet_37_r.text: ['Finding: Dr. G. Mills of WildCRU et al. show how cheetah hunting tactics vary according to their prey via @username ']
Biology_tweet_37_r.displayed_text: Finding: Dr. G. Mills of WildCRU et al. show how cheetah hunting tactics vary according to their prey via @username

Biology_tweet_37_p.News Context: Dr. G. Mills of WildCRU et al. show how cheetah hunting tactics vary according to their  prey via @username
Biology_tweet_37_p.Paper Context: Thus, the widely held belief that cheetah hunts consist of simple highspeed chases seems an oversimplification. Rather, we suggest that cheetah chases comprise two primary phases: (i) an initial rapid acceleration resulting in high speed to quickly catch up with prey, followed by (ii) a prey-specific slowing period that enables the cheetah to match turns instigated by prey as the distance between them closes. However, this formulation only considered forward acceleration and speed, ignoring lateral acceleration.

Biology_107_r.News Finding: "Dolphins simplified their calls to counter the masking effects of vessel noise."
Biology_107_r.Paper Finding: If a vessel is located in a different direction from conspecifics, there may be a decrease in masking (spatial release from masking) , but the observed changes in the whistle signals indicate that the dolphins simplified their calls to counter the masking effects of vessel noise.
Biology_107_r.News Context:
'The Shortest Answer Possible'

Communication Is very important for dolphins, and they rely on sounds to do so. This not just makes it difficult for them to communicate, but it masks their individual identification, and might also reduce the information in their whistles. "Dolphins simplified their calls to counter the masking effects of vessel noise."
Biology_107_r.Paper Context: The study area is adjacent to the shipping lanes into Delaware Bay (electronic supplementary material, figure S1 ) and had ambient noise levels comparable to other coastal areas with frequent vessel traffic . If a vessel is located in a different direction from conspecifics, there may be a decrease in masking (spatial release from masking) , but the observed changes in the whistle signals indicate that the dolphins simplified their calls to counter the masking effects of vessel noise. Ambient noise levels are likely to rise in the future as vessel traffic increases and an offshore wind energy facility is proposed.
Biology_107_r.text: ['Finding: "Dolphins simplified their calls to counter the masking effects of vessel noise."']
Biology_107_r.displayed_text: Finding: "Dolphins simplified their calls to counter the masking effects of vessel noise."
